awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Dynamic Thermal Interface Material for Cooling Medium and High Power Electronics
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project has the objective of demonstrating thermal interface material (D-TIM paste) at least twice as effective in use in packaging electronics with medium and high power loads as prior material.  A major focus is on enabling novel mode of heat transfer at the walls of a thermal stack and within the thermal paste, while fulfilling other technical requirements for a TIM, such as minimal thermal contact (interfacial) resistance and compatible coefficient of thermal expansion.  The TIM concept investigated has a built-in performance enhancement as demands on the material increase.  Improved interfacial performance is the key to turning this interesting and promising material into product of commercial value.  The team has scientific and business experience appropriate to the task; it has identified measurement strategies and materials composition experiments likely to lead to TIM with low contact thermal impedance.  A balance of in-house resources and out-sourcing ensures successful completion of the work.  The work builds on the body of work of the last two decades in nanocarbon composite materials and exploitation of nonlinear responses of materials to selected stimulae.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is the consequence of a breakthrough solution to fill the need for fast thermal transport through thermal stacks for high speed, densely-packed, or high power electronics. The results of this project will refine understanding and performance of its proprietary materials to the point that commercialization becomes feasible.  This woman-owned company will supply unique thermal interface products and license intellectual property for use in computing devices, servers, telecommunications, motor control, and many diverse Industrial/military applications such as semiconductor, energy conversion, transportation, chemical manufacturing, and space satellite/probe thermal management. Improved heat dissipation is of environmental significance, as better thermal performance improves device lifetime, reduces material consumption, and allows greater device speed for a fixed-size heat sink.  Portable electronics reduces the need to move materials or people between locations, thus reducing fuel consumption and attendant pollution.  The TIM is likely to be useful for stationary heat transfer problems as well, such as solid state power supplies, fuel cells, power inverters, thermo-electric coolers, and motors.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Summary: Microelectronics supplants or replaces functions provided by electrical, chemical, or mechanical devices. Innovation in electronics has become the driver in all sectors of the economy, from entertainment to information, transportation, and energy industries. The rise of electronics is embodied by digital photography replacing photographic film. While making processes more versatile, faster and safer, electronics heavily relies on semiconductors. Excess heat kills; semiconductors are especially vulnerable. Anchor Science demonstrated the feasibility of using nanocarbon –based Dynamic Thermal Interface Material, D-TIM, in prototype pastes in cooling computer chips. Specifically, D-TIM reduced working temperature differences on personal computer processors by up to 20 centigrade between the idle and fully powered conditions compared to commercial thermal greases formulated with silver, or ceramic thermally-conductive fillers. The difference between our best prototypes and nanodiamond-containing benchmark amounts to 4 to 5 centigrade. The advantage of D-TIM grows with temperature, application power density, and with the size of the gap between parts filled with D-TIM in a thermal joint. Anchor confirmed that application with power densities of 10 watts per square centimeters or larger can benefit from use of the D-TIM in their thermal management. The company pursues developing and commercializing applications in thermal management of computing and power electronics.

Intellectual Merit: The dynamic TIM concept has a built-in performance enhancement as demands on the material increase.  Improved interfacial performance is the key to turning this interesting and promising material into a product of commercial value.  The team found materials that produce a targeted increase in thermal conductivity (contact and bulk) with growing temperature by exploring and improving testing strategies.  A combination of in-house resources, collaborative, and contractual relationships has yielded successful progress of the work.  Anchor’s advances build on the body of work of the last two decades in nanocarbon composite materials and exploitation of nonlinear responses of materials to selected stimulae. 

Broader Impacts: This woman-owned company has developed a breakthrough solution for fast thermal transport through medium and high power thermal stacks. The results of this project refined understanding and performance of Dynamic Thermal Interface Material (D-TIM) gels to the point that commercialization has become feasible. Improved heat dissipation is of environmental significance, as better thermal performance improves device lifetime, reduces material consumption, and speeds performance for a given energy load.  The D-TIM is likely to be useful for heat transfer solutions in areas as diverse as renewable energy capture, chemical manufacturing, hybrid and electric vehicles, and space satellite/probe thermal management.

Keywords:

1. Thermal interface materials,  2. Carbon nanotubes, 3. Graphene, 4. Carbon-based nanostructures,  5.  Cooling Electronics,   6. Thermal interfaces, 7.  Heat transfer coefficient,
8. Technological forecasting.

 

Topic and Subtopic: EC4. Packaging and Thermal Management


Last Modified: 10/30/2013
Modified by: Ewa S Kirkor
